text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
Organization 0..*Network
id S0..1id
meta S0..1Meta
text S0..1Narrative
extension 0..*ExtensionSlice: Unordered, Open by value:url
organization-period S0..1PeriodValid time period for this Network
URL: http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/organization-period
location-reference 0..*Reference(VhDir Location)Location
URL: http://hl7.org/fhir/uv/vhdir/StructureDefinition/location-reference
usage-restriction 0..*Reference(VhDir Restriction)Restriction
URL: http://hl7.org/fhir/uv/vhdir/StructureDefinition/usage-restriction
identifier 0..*IdentifierIdentifies this network across multiple systems
extension 0..*ExtensionSlice: Unordered, Open by value:url
identifier-status 1..1codeStatus
URL: http://hl7.org/fhir/uv/vhdir/StructureDefinition/identifier-status
Binding: VhDir Identifier Status Value Set (example)
assigner 0..1Reference(VhDir Organization)
active 1..1boolean
type 0..*CodeableConceptType
Binding: VhDir Network Type Value Set (example)
name S0..1stringName
alias S0..*stringAlternate names by which the Network is known
telecom 0..0
address S0..*Address
partOf S1..1Reference(VhDir Organization | VhDir OrganizationAffiliation)Reference to organization that owns the network
contact 0..*BackboneElement
name 0..1HumanName
family 1..1string
given 1..*string
telecom 0..*ContactPoint
extension 0..*ExtensionSlice: Unordered, Open by value:url
contactpoint-availabletime 0..*(Complex)Available time
URL: http://hl7.org/fhir/uv/vhdir/StructureDefinition/contactpoint-availabletime
contactpoint-viaintermediary 0..1Reference(VhDir Practitionerrole | VhDir Organization | VhDir OrganizationAffiliation | VhDir Location)viaintermediary
URL: http://hl7.org/fhir/uv/vhdir/StructureDefinition/contactpoint-viaintermediary
system 1..1code
value 1..1string
endpoint 0..*Reference(VhDir Endpoint)

Documentation for this format

name: VhdirNetwork
title: VhDir Network
description: Defines the properties of a Network (through extending an Organization resource) for use in a Validated Healthcare Directory

element.definition: The details of a healthcare provider insurance network

constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource or SHALL refer to the containing resource
constraint.expression: contained.where((('#'+id in (%resource.descendants().reference | %resource.descendants().as(canonical) | %resource.descendants().as(uri) | %resource.descendants().as(url))) or descendants().where(reference = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists()).not()).trace('unmatched', id).empty()
constraint.xpath: not(exists(for $contained in f:contained return $contained[not(parent::*/descendant::f:reference/@value=concat('#', $contained/*/id/@value) or descendant::f:reference[@value='#'])]))

extension.valueMarkdown: When a resource has no narrative, only systems that fully understand the data can display the resource to a human safely. Including a guman readable representation in the resource makes for a much more robust eco-system and cheaper handling of resources by intermediary systems. Some ecosystems restrict distribution of resources to only those systems that do fully understand the resources, and as a consequence implementers may believe that the narrative is superfluous. However experience shows that such eco-systems often open up to new participants over time.

constraint.human: A resource should have narrative for robust management
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a security label
The organization SHALL at least have a name or an id, and possibly more than one

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.
element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

element.definition: An Extension

element.short: Valid time period for this Network
element.definition: An Extension

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: An Extension

Identifies and conveys information about restrictions on the use or release of exchanged information, e.g. information that can only be shared under particular condition, such as a signed data use agreement between parties

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the resource that contains them

element.short: Identifies this network  across multiple systems
element.definition: Identifier for the network that is used to identify the network across multiple disparate systems.
Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: An Extension
An Extension
Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: identifies the meaning of the extension
element.definition: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL.
element.comment: The definition may point directly to a computable or human-readable definition of the extensibility codes, or it may be a logical URI as declared in some other specification. The definition SHALL be a URI for the Structure Definition defining the extension.

element.label: status
element.definition: Describes the status of an identifier

element.short: usual | official | temp | secondary | old (If known)
element.definition: The purpose of this identifier.
element.comment: Applications can assume that an identifier is permanent unless it explicitly says that it is temporary.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate identifier for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of identifiers.
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary id for a permanent one.

binding.description: Identifies the purpose for this identifier, if known .

element.definition: A coded type for the identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.
element.comment: This element deals only with general categories of identifiers.  It SHOULD not be used for codes that correspond 1..1 with the Identifier.system. Some identifiers may fall into multiple categories due to common usage.   Where the system is known, a type is unnecessary because the type is always part of the system definition. However systems often need to handle identifiers where the system is not known. There is not a 1:1 relationship between type and system, since many different systems have the same type.
element.requirements: Allows users to make use of identifiers when the identifier system is not known.

binding.description: A coded type for an identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.

element.short: The namespace for the identifier value
element.definition: Establishes the namespace for the value - that is, a URL that describes a set values that are unique.
element.comment: Identifier.system is always case sensitive.
element.requirements: There are many sets  of identifiers.  To perform matching of two identifiers, we need to know what set we're dealing with. The system identifies a particular set of unique identifiers.

element.definition: The portion of the identifier typically relevant to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
element.comment: If the value is a full URI, then the system SHALL be urn:ietf:rfc:3986.  The value's primary purpose is computational mapping.  As a result, it may be normalized for comparison purposes (e.g. removing non-significant whitespace, dashes, etc.)  A value formatted for human display can be conveyed using the [Rendered Value extension](extension-rendered-value.html). Identifier.value is to be treated as case sensitive unless knowledge of the Identifier.system allows the processer to be confident that non-case-sensitive processing is safe.

mapping.map: II.extension or II.root if system indicates OID or GUID (Or Role.id.extension or root)

element.short: Time period when id is/was valid for use
element.definition: Time period during which identifier is/was valid for use.

element.short: Organization that issued id (may be just text)
element.definition: Organization that issued/manages the identifier.
element.comment: The Identifier.assigner may omit the .reference element and only contain a .display element reflecting the name or other textual information about the assigning organization.

mapping.map: II.assigningAuthorityName but note that this is an improper use by the definition of the field.  Also Role.scoper

element.label: status
element.short: Whether the organization's record is still in active use
element.definition: Whether the organization's record is still in active use.
element.comment:
This active flag is not intended to be used to mark an organization as temporarily closed or under construction. Instead the Location(s) within the Organization should have the suspended status. If further details of the reason for the suspension are required, then an extension on this element should be used.

This element is labeled as a modifier because it may be used to mark that the resource was created in error.
element.requirements: Need a flag to indicate a record is no longer to be used and should generally be hidden for the user in the UI.
element.meaningWhenMissing: This resource is generally assumed to be active if no value is provided for the active element
element.isModifierReason: This element is labelled as a modifier because it is a status element that can indicate that a record should not be treated as valid

mapping.map: ./Status (however this concept in ServD more covers why the organization is active or not, could be delisted, deregistered, not operational yet) this could alternatively be derived from ./StartDate and ./EndDate and given a context date.

element.definition: Type of network
element.comment:
Organizations can be corporations, wards, sections, clinical teams, government departments, etc. Note that code is generally a classifier of the type of organization; in many applications, codes are used to identity a particular organization (say, ward) as opposed to another of the same type - these are identifiers, not codes

When considering if multiple types are appropriate, you should evaluate if child organizations would be a more appropriate use of the concept, as different types likely are in different sub-areas of the organization. This is most likely to be used where type values have orthogonal values, such as a religious, academic and medical center.

We expect that some jurisdictions will profile this optionality to be a single cardinality.
element.requirements: Need to be able to track the kind of organization that this is - different organization types have different uses.

element.label: Network Name
element.definition: A name associated with the network (official name designated by the owner of the network).
element.comment: If the name of an network changes, consider putting the old name in the alias column so that it can still be located through searches.
element.requirements: Need to use the name as the label of the network.

element.label: alias
element.short: Alternate names by which the Network is known
element.definition: A list of alternate names that the network is known as, or was known as in the past.
element.comment: There are no dates associated with the alias/historic names, as this is not intended to track when names were used, but to assist in searching so that older names can still result in identifying the network.
element.requirements:
Over time networks may go through many changes and may be known by different names to different users.

For searching knowing previous names that the network was known by can be very useful.

element.short: A contact detail for the organization
element.definition: A contact detail for the organization.
element.comment: The use code 'home' is not to be used. Note that these contacts are not the contact details of people who are employed by or represent the organization, but official contacts for the organization itself.
element.requirements: Human contact for the organization.

constraint.human: The telecom of an organization can never be of use 'home'

element.definition: An address for the organization.
element.comment: Organization may have multiple addresses with different uses or applicable periods. The use code 'home' is not to be used.
element.requirements: May need to keep track of the organization's addresses for contacting, billing or reporting requirements.

constraint.human: An address of an organization can never be of use 'home'

element.short: Reference to organization that owns the network
element.definition: The organization that "owns" this network (typically a payer)
element.requirements: Need to specify the payor organization of this network

element.short: Contact for the organization for a certain purpose
element.definition: Contact for the organization for a certain purpose.
element.comment: Where multiple contacts for the same purpose are provided there is a standard extension that can be used to determine which one is the preferred contact to use.
element.requirements: Need to keep track of assigned contact points within bigger organization.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.definition: Indicates a purpose for which the contact can be reached.
element.requirements: Need to distinguish between multiple contact persons.

binding.description: The purpose for which you would contact a contact party.

element.short: A name associated with the contact
element.definition: A name associated with the contact.
element.requirements: Need to be able to track the person by name.

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: usual | official | temp | nickname | anonymous | old | maiden
element.definition: Identifies the purpose for this name.
element.comment: Applications can assume that a name is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate name for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of names.
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old name etc.for a current/permanent one

binding.description: The use of a human name.

mapping.map: XPN.7, but often indicated by which field contains the name

element.short: Text representation of the full name
element.definition: Specifies the entire name as it should be displayed e.g. on an application UI. This may be provided instead of or as well as the specific parts.
element.comment: Can provide both a text representation and parts. Applications updating a name SHALL ensure that when both text and parts are present,  no content is included in the text that isn't found in a part.
element.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.

element.definition: The part of a name that links to the genealogy. In some cultures (e.g. Eritrea) the family name of a son is the first name of his father.
element.comment: Family Name may be decomposed into specific parts using extensions (de, nl, es related cultures).

element.short: Given names (not always 'first'). Includes middle names
element.definition: Given name.
element.comment: If only initials are recorded, they may be used in place of the full name parts. Initials may be separated into multiple given names but often aren't due to paractical limitations.  This element is not called "first name" since given names do not always come first.
element.orderMeaning: Given Names appear in the correct order for presenting the name

element.short: Parts that come before the name
element.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the start of the name.
element.orderMeaning: Prefixes appear in the correct order for presenting the name

element.short: Parts that come after the name
element.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the end of the name.
element.orderMeaning: Suffixes appear in the correct order for presenting the name

element.short: Time period when name was/is in use
element.definition: Indicates the period of time when this name was valid for the named person.
element.requirements: Allows names to be placed in historical context.

element.short: Contact details (telephone, email, etc.)  for a contact
element.definition: A contact detail (e.g. a telephone number or an email address) by which the party may be contacted.
element.requirements: People have (primary) ways to contact them in some way such as phone, email.

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.label: viaintermediary
element.definition: Represents an external point of contact responsible for handling communications with this entity

element.short: phone | fax | email | pager | url | sms | other
element.definition: Telecommunications form for contact point - what communications system is required to make use of the contact.
The actual contact point details, in a form that is meaningful to the designated communication system (i.e. phone number or email address).
element.comment: Additional text data such as phone extension numbers, or notes about use of the contact are sometimes included in the value.
element.requirements: Need to support legacy numbers that are not in a tightly controlled format.

element.short: home | work | temp | old | mobile - purpose of this contact point
element.definition: Identifies the purpose for the contact point.
element.comment: Applications can assume that a contact is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Need to track the way a person uses this contact, so a user can choose which is appropriate for their purpose.
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old contact etc.for a current/permanent one

mapping.map: XTN.2 - but often indicated by field

element.short: Specify preferred order of use (1 = highest)
element.definition: Specifies a preferred order in which to use a set of contacts. ContactPoints with lower rank values are more preferred than those with higher rank values.
element.comment: Note that rank does not necessarily follow the order in which the contacts are represented in the instance.

element.short: Time period when the contact point was/is in use
element.definition: Time period when the contact point was/is in use.

element.short: Visiting or postal addresses for the contact
element.definition: Visiting or postal addresses for the contact.
element.requirements: May need to keep track of a contact party's address for contacting, billing or reporting requirements.

element.short: Technical endpoints providing access to services operated for the organization
element.definition: Technical endpoints providing access to services operated for the organization.
element.requirements: Organizations have multiple systems that provide various services and need to be able to define the technical connection details for how to connect to them, and for what purpose.

element.definition: The details of a healthcare provider insurance network

element.short: Valid time period for this Network

element.definition: Identifies and conveys information about restrictions on the use or release of exchanged information, e.g. information that can only be shared under particular condition, such as a signed data use agreement between parties

element.short: Identifies this network  across multiple systems
element.definition: Identifier for the network that is used to identify the network across multiple disparate systems.
Type of network

element.label: Network Name
element.definition: A name associated with the network (official name designated by the owner of the network).
element.comment: If the name of an network changes, consider putting the old name in the alias column so that it can still be located through searches.
element.requirements: Need to use the name as the label of the network.

element.label: alias
element.short: Alternate names by which the Network is known
element.definition: A list of alternate names that the network is known as, or was known as in the past.
element.comment: There are no dates associated with the alias/historic names, as this is not intended to track when names were used, but to assist in searching so that older names can still result in identifying the network.
element.requirements:
Over time networks may go through many changes and may be known by different names to different users.

For searching knowing previous names that the network was known by can be very useful.

element.short: Reference to organization that owns the network
element.definition: The organization that "owns" this network (typically a payer)
element.requirements: Need to specify the payor organization of this network
